Problem:
Consider a controlled system which is governed by the differential equation \\(\\dot{x} = Dx\\) where D is a linear operator. An external control is modeled by multipling the state vector \\(x(t)\\) by a matrix exponential \\( e^{Mt} \), where M is a time-independent matrix and t is the time variable.

If the state vector \\(x_0\\) at t = 0 is transformed by \\( e^{Mt}x_0 \\) and then allowed to evolve in accordance with \\(\\dot{x} = Dx\\) without any further transformation, will the state at time T, \\(x(T)\\), be the same as if only \\(\\dot{x} = Dx\\) with the initial condition \\(x_0\\) had been applied?
Explanation: Applying the transformation \\( e^{Mt} \\) modifies the initial state vector \\(x_0\\), hence the system evolves from this new state. Unless M commutes with D, the final state \\(x(T)\\) will differ due to the differing initial state and interaction effects between D and M.
